awd_titl_txt: Training Successful Trajectories: Interventions to Increase Minority Student and Future Engineering and Other STEM Faculty Application Success Rates
awd_abstract_narration:
Many communities of color remain significantly underrepresented at the doctoral level in all STEM fields; the engineering fields are particularly difficult to increase racial and ethnic representation among domestic groups. Many doctoral applicants of color, who are otherwise well-qualified in education and experience, are underserved in the area of graduate school application support, specifically in the development of self-presentation skills necessary to win a major fellowship, gain admission to graduate school, and land a quality position in their field. While underrepresented students at well-resourced universities and colleges are offered recruitment for fellowships, preparation workshops, and professional advising to develop such self-presentation skills, these services are often lacking at institutions of higher learning that do not have the human and financial resources to offer such professionalization training. Without this support, many underrepresented doctoral students are less likely to be successful in securing a fellowship and are gaining admission to complete graduate school. This grant project focuses on remedying this issue by offering underrepresented undergraduate and graduate students, and postdoctoral scholars, who will all be future faculty, the kind of self-presentation training offered during that Boot Camp (and at well-resourced universities and colleges), and using measurable outcomes to test the efficacy of four different types of intervention.

This project has immense potential broadening participation in engineering and other STEM field by studying and comparing four different interventions for underrepresented students, and the findings from the research study will provide practical insights into the most effective training of vital professional development skills. Over two years, ninety underrepresented students, along with future faculty (e.g., postdocs) and current faculty, will receive first-rate training. By assessing participant knowledge, their application numbers, and the results of their applications, the investigators will evaluate content delivery, consultation efficacy, and the effectiveness of training methods and materials. After participating in this program, the 90 trainees (e.g., LSAMP students, postdocs, and faculty) will take their training with them; this training will positively influence their professional trajectories throughout their careers. Beyond training these future leaders, the most important result of the project will be the compilation, analysis, and dissemination of the research findings to a broad audience, so that future programs across the country will have the benefit of research into which types of training content and delivery methods most successfully support URM STEM students (and current and future faculty) with applications to graduate school, fellowships, and grants.
org_div_long_name: Division of Engineering Education and Centers

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: VILLANOVA UNIVERSITY IN THE STATE OF PENNSYLVANIA

por.por_cntn:
This project provided training in skills that were hypothesized to increase participants' success in applications to the NSF Graduate Research Fellowship Program (GRFP), other competitive awards, and graduate school. To evaluate the effectiveness of our training program and compare different delivery methods, 207 student participants were recruited and randomly assigned to different treatment groups or a control group. All participants were members of the NSF Louis Stokes Alliances for Minority Participation (LSAMP), which are designed to identify and support high achieving Underrepresented Minority (URM) students in STEM.

Study participants received the same training in one of four delivery methods: (1) in person spread out over five weeks, (2) as an accelerated program over three days at a conference, (3) spread out over five weeks as a synchronous online class, or (4) as a series of online workshop videos viewed asynchronously over months. Control group participants received none of the program's training. Additionally, for the four treatment groups, half of the participants were randomly selected to receive access to unlimited one-on-one consultations with professional grant specialists after their training program ended, until after the following NSF GRFP application deadline.

A particular strength of this study is the fact so many students from the relevant population--academically gifted students from URM groups--were randomly assigned to the different training and control groups, which suggests that any differences in the outcome are likely caused by the training.

Our data show that students who received the training were more likely to be recognized by the NSF GRFP, and that the probable reasons are that the training increases both the likelihood a student will apply and the likelihood they will be recognized. 25% of all participants who received the training were recognized by the NSF GRFP (i.e., were awarded or received Honorable Mention), while only 4% of control participants were recognized.

Among the participants who applied to graduate school, those who received the training were accepted into a significantly greater number of PhD programs. This was likely because the participants who received the training were significantly more likely to apply to PhD programs rather than to master's or professional programs only.

In addition to the one- and two-year follow-up data, participants were also asked to complete surveys before and after their training. These surveys assessed their intentions to apply to fellowships and graduate school, understanding of the application process, confidence in their chances of succeeding, and levels of imposter syndrome traits.

Participants from all training groups were able to name significantly more fellowships to which they intended to apply than the control group, and the number of fellowships to which they intended to apply was significantly correlated with the actual number to which they applied.

Many of the participants who went on to win the NSF GRF or other awards credited their participation in the training with being critical to their success and sent unsolicited emails to the presenters--even years after the training--thanking them for the impact of the program.

Importantly, these results also suggest that the delivery method for the training did not impact results, nor was access to ongoing professional consultations necessary for student success. Thus in-person, accelerated, and online delivery methods are expected to be effective, and the expensive feature of providing ongoing access to professional consultants after the training appears not to be necessary. However, there is evidence that interaction with the presenters and a live delivery of the material--either in-person or virtually--leads to greater participant satisfaction and more improvement in participant confidence and perceived understanding.

The workshop presenters will continue to work with LSAMP leaders and the Southern Regional Education Board, as well as other partners, to make these workshops available to more URM students in the future. Since the project tested the shorter- and longer-term effects of the training, some data are still outstanding. The final surveys--the two-year follow up from the Spring 2021 cohort--will be completed in May 2023. A publication addressing the findings from the full duration of the study will follow.

 

Expert participants in this project included:

Dr. Angela Birkes: Alliance Director, Peach State LSAMP; Office of Institutional Diversity; University of Georgia

Dr. Stephen Cox: Alliance Director, Greater Philadelphia LSAMP; Drexel University

Dr. Tamara Floyd-Smith: Assistant Provost; Tuskegee University

Dr. Felicia Jefferson: Director, Neuroscience and Bioengineering Laboratories; Fort Valley State University

Dr. Erick C. Jones, Sr.: Associate Dean for Graduate Studies, College of Engineering; University of Texas at Arlington

Dr. Nyree McDonald: Associate Dean, Recruitment and Admissions, the Graduate School; University of Notre Dame

Dr. Teresa A. Nance: Chief Diversity Officer and Vice President for Diversity and Inclusion; Villanova University

Dr. Collette Patt: Director, Berkeley LSAMP and Director, University of California NSF-AGEP Alliance; University of California-Berkeley

Dr. Eric Sheppard: Dean of the School of Engineering and Technology (2004-2016), Hampton University; previous NSF GRFP Program Manager


Last Modified: 11/04/2021
Modified by: Michael Westrate
